The reason scientists don't go and prove it is because the government of the country won't let scientists in to study it.

 Actually, Turkey has been an ally of the United States for a long, long time. Generally, Americans (even fundy christians) are welcome there. A good friend of mine was stationed there some years ago.
 
 Perhaps you are unaware of where Ararat is. It is in a part of Turkey very close to Georgia, Armenia, Iran. There is fighting going on there from time to time. Just to the south is Kurdistan (not a country but a region that overlaps Iraq, Iran and Turkey) and Iraq. The area just to the south of Lake Van (which is just south of Mt. Ararat) is where the U.S. would like to stage troops to invade Iraq. 
 
 While you are welcome in Turkey (even fundy christians are welcome), no one, not even Muslims are allowed into that part of Turkey unless they have a really, really good reason. Religious quests don't seem to be a good reason to the Turks.

 The Noachian flood was obviously the one in question.

A couple of things. First of all, the ark would not have to be enormous because it probably did not carry all of the animals that we see today. That would explain the dying out of many dinosaurs, preserving their fossils in the rocks today. Also, the sea creatures would not have to be taken aboard as well as the freshwater creatures because of the fact that the entire planet would be covered with water. For plants, only seeds would be needed.
 Also, one theory that is commonly overlooked is the creation "evolutionist" theory. This theory states that God created "mutts," animals with the entire genetic code and no specialization (basically he created the genus or order, not the individual species except for man). Thus, two dogs could give rise to many other mutts that, when they moved or faced hard times, would like Darwin's finches weed out undesirable genetic code for the environment. All in all, it's more likely that all of the animals came from an ark than from nonliving matter.
